Saccharomycopsis crataegensis is a species of yeast that belongs to the genus Saccharomycopsis. It is a ascomycetous fungus that was first isolated from the leaves of the hawthorn tree (Crataegus) in China.

The main features of Saccharomycopsis crataegensis are as follows:

1. Cell morphology: The cells are typically ellipsoidal to cylindrical in shape, measuring around 3-6 μm in width and 5-10 μm in length.

2. Reproduction: Saccharomycopsis crataegensis reproduces asexually through budding, where new cells emerge as outgrowths from the parent cell.

3. Habitat and substrate: This yeast species is typically found in association with the leaves and other plant material of the hawthorn tree (Crataegus spp.). It is believed to be a saprotroph, obtaining nutrients from the decaying organic matter in its natural environment.

4. Physiological characteristics: Saccharomycopsis crataegensis is able to ferment a variety of sugars, including glucose, sucrose, and maltose, to produce ethanol and carbon dioxide as byproducts.

5. Taxonomy and phylogeny: Saccharomycopsis crataegensis is classified within the phylum Ascomycota, class Saccharomycetes, and the family Saccharomycopsidaceae. Genetic analyses have shown it to be closely related to other Saccharomycopsis species.

Overall, Saccharomycopsis crataegensis is a yeast species that plays a role in the decomposition of plant material in its natural habitat and has potential applications in various fermentation processes.
